I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) aims to support the Vientiane Sustainable Urban Transport 
Project1 through strengthening  the  capacity of  the government  to implement the high-level 
technology features of the ongoing project to ensure successful implementation and sustainable 
operation. Vientiane is the capital and largest city in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR). The city is experiencing ever increasing land transport congestion and related problems of 
increased number of accidents, deteriorating air quality, and increased greenhouse gas emissions. 
The ongoing project is designed to increase the quality of life for people in Vientiane by improving 
access to and mobility within the city.  
 
2.  Impact,  outcome,  and  outputs.  The  impact  of  the  ongoing  project  will  be  an 
environmentally sustainable and pedestrian-friendly transport system developed in Vientiane. The 
outcome will be improved urban transport operations and capacity in Vientiane. The project will 
have five outputs:  
 
(i)  A sustainable transport management entity for Vientiane established. The entity 
will manage operations of systems and facilities to be developed under the project as 
well as future sustainable transport operations.  
(ii) High-quality bus services and bus rapid transit established and operating in 
Vientiane. The project will develop 11.5 kilometers (km) of bus rapid transit (BRT) 
corridors in the center of Vientiane, dedicated to BRT services. The new BRT buses 
will serve a network of 84.0 kilometers of routes covering much of the city. Operation 
of the BRT buses will be tendered out to private operators.  
(iii) Traffic management in the core area of Vientiane improved. The project will 
introduce  measures to  improve  traffic  management so  that  traffic  moves  more 
efficiently in Vientiane.  These measures will include installing or upgrading traffic 
signals, providing new road markings and signage, and establishing a central traffic 
control center using the latest technology.  
(iv) Paid parking system and national vehicle registration system established. A new 
on-street  paid  parking  system  will  be  established  that  uses  electronic  meter 
technology. Also, a national electronic vehicle registration system will be established 
that facilitates enforcement of parking regulations. Both systems will be implemented 
by private firms.  
(v) Accessibility  for pedestrians and non-motorized transport in the core area of 
Vientiane improved. The project will improve pedestrian facilities near BRT stations. 
In addition, the project will finance the demonstration of modern electric-assist vehicles 
as a possible replacement for existing highly polluting vehicles.  
 
3.  Financing amounts. The ongoing project costs $99.70 million, of which $35.00 million 
equivalent was approved on 10 March 2015 as a concessional loan from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to finance the project. The government also acquired (i) a loan of $15.00 million from 
the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries Fund for International Development (OFID), 
                                                 
1 ADB.  2015. Report and Recommendation of the President to  the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and 
Administration of Loan and Grant to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for the Vientiane Sustainable Urban 
Transport Project. Manila.

2 
(ii) a grant of $1.84 million from the Global Environment Facility, (iii) a loan of $20.00 million from 
the European Investment Bank, and (iv) a grant of $6.90 million equivalent from the European 
Union’s Asian Investment Facility. Private sector investment estimated at $6.41 million will finance 
the parking system and the electronic vehicle registration system. The government will contribute 
$14.55 million, of which taxes comprise $7.13 million.  
 
4.  Project performance. The project became effective  on 29 August  2016.2 As of 26 
January 2018, the cumulative number of contracts awarded for ADB financing is $572,400 but 
only $261,000 has been disbursed. The urban transport advisor commenced services on 7 
October 2016. As of 15 January 2018, the Ministry of Public Works and Transport (MPWT) is 
recruiting a consulting firm as project implementation consultant to undertake institutional design 
for the new entity, detailed engineering design, project management, and implementation services. 
The contract is expected to be awarded in Q1 2018.3 ADB and EIB fielded a joint review mission 
in January 2018 focusing on expediting project implementation. The Mission met with the Minister 
of MPWT, Vice Mayor of Vientiane, and other senior officials, and agreed with the government on 
actions to improve project implementation.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
5.  The ongoing project is complex and utilizes high-level technologies and systems that are 
new to the Lao PDR: (i) a BRT system with centralized control center, (ii) a smart parking fee 
collection system, (iii) an electronic vehicle registration system, an intelligent transport system for 
traffic  management,  and  (iv)  non-motorized  transport  vehicles.  The  ongoing  project  has 
experienced  the  following  issues: (i)  delays  in  declaring  effectiveness and  recruitment of 
consultants, and (ii) the difficulty in decision making due to lack of knowledge among decision 
makers.  The  TRTA  will  address  these  issues  by  financing  capacity  development  and 
implementation support for the decision makers.  
 
6.  The ongoing project includes implementation support and capacity building for the project 
coordination unit through the assistance of project consultants and mobilization of a quality control 
consultant to support the operation  of the new transport management entity  (para.  2[i]) in 
monitoring operators of the bus and parking companies.  However, it has become apparent that 
more capacity building will be needed than was anticipated during project processing to ensure 
for the project’s timely and efficient implementation. The decision makers in the government need 
up-to-date  knowledge of technical  and operational  aspects of  urban transport  management 
entities to be able to manage the implementation of the project and continue managing the system 
after  project  completion.  While  the  project  envisions  contracting  out  key  tasks to  private 
companies on an ongoing basis, getting good performance out of the private companies requires 
that the government understands what they need out of these companies and how to get it. 
Capacity building  need  for the  government is thus paramount in  ensuring  efficient project 
implementation and sustainable operation after physical completion.  Given these needs, this 
TRTA will focus on strengthening (i) institutional  capacity for the establishment of the new 
                                                 
2  The delay in declaring ADB loan and Global Environment Facility grant effectiveness was due to the delay in meeting 
the financing agreements’ cross-effectiveness condition, which required that all the cofinancing loans and grants 
must have met their own effectiveness conditions before the ADB loan and Global Environment Facility could be 
declared effective. 
3  The award of the contract has been delayed due to the time required to address representations were made by two 
of the bidders.

3 
transport entity, (ii) knowledge of new technologies and systems among decision makers, and (iii) 
capacity of the new transport entity.     
 
7.  First, institutional capacity for the establishment of the new urban transport entity should 
be strengthened. The establishment of this new entity is essential to the success of the project 
since it is expected to (i) manage private sector firms providing services, (ii) ensure that services 
provided are of high quality, (iii) manage daily operation of the system, (iv) plan and implement 
future development of the system, and (v) communicate with the public and key stakeholders. 
Although project consultants will support implementation, the executing agency needs to take 
legal, fiscal, and political actions and coordination among related authorities will be required to 
establish the new entity. The TA will help facilitate the discussion among the related authorities 
so that they  understand  and  comply with  the legal,  fiscal, and political  processes for the 
establishment of the new transport management entity.   
 
8.  Second, knowledge of new technologies and systems among the decision makers should 
be augmented. The project coordination unit will prepare proposed plans and designs for each 
output component of the project with help from the project consultants. Since these proposals 
include technologies and systems new to the Lao PDR, the decision-makers in the executing 
agency and the related government authorities who will review and evaluate them need to be 
knowledgeable of current technology and operation models. Therefore, the knowledge of new 
technologies and systems, e.g., merits and demerits, potential risks, and alternative options, 
should be developed  among the decision makers in the executing  agency and the related 
government authorities to create the foundation for timely and appropriate decision making. The 
support provided by TA consultants to reviewing and evaluating the proposals will also help to 
develop the capacity of the decision makers.   
 
9.  Third, it is crucial for the  new entity to strengthen  its knowledge on urban transport 
management. The new entity will manage the daily operation of the public transport systems, 
manage the private firms operating the BRT, parking, and vehicle registration systems, and plan 
for the future development of the system. The knowledge of the staff in the new entity should 
match that of the private firms and be sufficient for daily operation and future development. Since 
the project will install technologies and systems that are new to the Lao PDR, staff in the new 
entity will not have experience with them. Therefore, intensive capacity building is needed for the 
staff of the new entity.  
 
10.  The government has requested ADB’s help to address capacity building.4 This TA is 
included in the country operations business plan for Lao PDR, 2018–2020.5    
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
11.  The TA  will  ensure the  effective  implementation of  the project and  the sustainable 
operation of the facilities developed through the capacity building of government staff. The TA will 
supplement  the  capacity  building  services  contracted  under  the  ongoing  project  and  TA 
consultants will regularly coordinate with project consultants to avoid duplication of efforts. While 
the project consultants will be focused on providing organizational management and project 
administration support to the day-to-day  operations of the project coordination unit,  the TA 
consultants will focus mainly on capacity building of the key government officials involved in the 
decision-making process, the stakeholders critical to the project’s success, and the staff of the 
                                                 
4 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 6 October 2017. 
5 ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Lao People’s Democratic Republic 2018-2020. Manila.

4 
new entity. ADB’s project team and the project coordination unit will organize periodic meetings 
between TA consultants and the project consultants and/or contractors to achieve effective 
coordination.    
  
12.  Output 1: Up-to-date knowledge on tasks and legal structure of traffic management 
entity shared among relevant government agencies.  The component will provide up-to-date 
knowledge of tasks and legal structures of the urban transport management entity to related 
authorities, including the Ministry of Public Works and Transport, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of 
Home Affairs, Traffic Police,  and Vientiane  Authority.  First, the latest and advanced  urban 
transport entities in other countries will be studied, and the TA will organize study tours for the 
government officials to the relevant countries (though the travel cost for the government officials 
will not be financed by the TA).  Based on the study, the TA will propose options for legal form 
and tasks of the new entity under the current legal and public administrative environment in the 
Lao PDR. The TA will also facilitate discussion among the relevant authorities to help them build 
a common understanding. The components will be implemented during 2018.   
 
13.  Output 2:  Knowledge of advanced technologies and  systems  among  decision 
makers developed. Knowledge will be developed through workshops, seminars, and individual 
communications held in 2018. In addition, supplemental workshops and/or seminars will be held 
in 2019 and 2020 to strengthen the knowledge. The knowledge building will include (i) the new 
bus system: design and operation of BRT, and coordination of BRT and existing bus service; (ii)  
traffic management: the latest methods and equipment for traffic management, and the role of the 
traffic management center;  (iii) on-street parking management: the latest fee collection system 
and enforcement of fee levying; (iv) electronic vehicle registration system: the latest electronic 
vehicle registration system and the function of the vehicle registration system;  (v) public–private 
partnership (PPP): the structure and potential risks of the project’s PPP; (vi) gender: why gender 
matters in  urban  transport  and  how  to  address  gender  in  urban  transport  planning  and 
management; and (vii) communication, marketing, branding, and advertising and their role. The 
learning materials for each field will be prepared both in English and Lao for future decision 
makers. The TA will also provide support in reviewing and evaluating the proposals prepared by 
the project consultants.  
 
14.  Output 3: Capacity of the newly established entity on urban transport management 
developed. The new entity will (i) manage the private sector firms operating BRT and the parking 
and vehicle registration system; (ii) ensure the high quality of service; (iii) manage the daily 
operations of the public transport system; and (iv) plan for future development of the system. The 
TA will develop the capacity of the new entity through workshops, seminars, and training. The 
capacity building will include, but not limited to (i) the operation and maintenance of BRT; (ii) 
operation and fee collection of on-street parking; (iii) structure and risks of vehicle registration 
system; (iv) operation of traffic management system; (v) latest non-motorized transport (NMT) 
vehicles  and  pedestrian  friendly  design;  (vi)  gender  issues  in  urban  transport  planning, 
management, and employment; (vii) options for the concession arrangement for the PPP and 
potential risks of the PPP concessions; (viii) the roles and measures of communication, marketing, 
branding, and advertising; and (ix) the organizational operation and management of the new entity. 
Capacity building will be implemented after the entity is established and staff are hired in 2020.  
Also, the learning materials for future staff will be prepared both in English and Lao.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the High-Level Technology Fund and administered by ADB.6 The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
16.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space in the MPWT or the Department of Transport, access to all relevant information, data and 
reports, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements

are in para. 19).

18.  Consulting services. The TA will use a consulting firm to provide capacity development 
in the technical aspect of urban transport management. The consulting firm will be recruited using 
the quality- and cost-based selection method with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio and a full technical 
proposal.  It is estimated that the consultant will be required to provide 33.5 person-months of 
international  consultancy services and 54 person-months of national consultancy services to 
deliver  all TA  outputs. The firm’s contract will be time-based. The consultants will work in 
cooperation with the urban transport advisor and the project implementation consultant. ADB will 
engage the consulting firm and procure all TA-financed goods (if applicable) in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017,  as amended  from time to  time) and  associated project 
administration instructions and technical assistance staff instructions.7

19.  Eligibility  of High-Level Technology Fund. The  TA  is eligible  for  the  High-Level 
Technology Fund since the TA aims to develop the capacity of the government stakeholders in 
using high-level technologies.8  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to the Government 
of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic to be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level 
Technology Fund for the Capacity Building for Vientiane Sustainable Urban Transport Project, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                 
8  The  High-Level Technology Fund supports TA  projects for  project identification and development, project 
preparation, project implementation and operation, pilot activities, capacity development, and research and policy 
advice for integration and scaling up of high-level technology and innovative solutions in project design and 
implementation. ADB. 2017. Establishment of the High-Level Technology Fund. Manila.
